posts.name: Kaden Morrison
posts.cooked: Does anyone have a step-by-step guide for setting up the VH-109 as an access point for at-home practice? I configured one of my radios as an access point and the other as a robot radio, but that doesn’t seem to work. I’ve tried configuring the access point, but that also didn’t work. Any help would be much appreciated.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
Have you seen the WPILib documentation ?

Can you give us any more details than that didn’t seem to work?  What were the lights on the radios showing?  They both had the same key?

kmminer:

configuring the access point

What does this mean?  Did you use the “Access Point Variant” firmware?  (Please don’t I don’t think that is what you want / need)

link_counts.title: Programming your Radio — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked: We are also having this problem. We have the access point configured and the two radios are connected (the SYS light is solid and the blue 6GHz light is on) but we can’t seem to access the RIO through this connection. Any help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: A lot of times we’ve seen this issue be caused by teams not setting their team number on the roborio 2. Make sure you’ve done this, and also that usb connection works.

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked: We have out team number set correctly. When we USB into the RIO directly, we can’t see the radio. When we run the radio in 2.4 mode everything works, except for the coms issues with 2.4 being congested.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Can you share a screenshot of the roborio imaging tool with your rio info shown?

SoggyToastEater:

When we USB into the RIO directly, we can’t see the radio.

Also, just wanted to confirm that this is normal

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked:
aeriuheuirherfer 737×423 43.2 KB What’s weird is that the roborio imaging tool can see the RIO over the access point connection at 10.44.99.2, but I can’t ping 10.44.99.2. I don’t think it’s a problem with the RIO, because it works perfectly fine over 2.4 GHz, but I could be wrong.

aeriuheuirherfer 737×423 43.2 KB

aeriuheuirherfer 737×423 43.2 KB

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: You’re powering the AP from a regulated source, right? The AP can’t be powered by a battery.

link_counts.title: [FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked: Yes, we are using POE from an outlet

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Ah, I was responding to OP.  Since you can see the RIO through the imaging tool, the radio link has to be active.  I hope it also means your network adapter is functioning and has the correct IP.

If you can see it over 2.4 GHz, that means the team number has to be set correctly in the DS .

I assume the things that specifically don’t work over the 6E radio link are ping, deploying code, Driver Station says it’s not connected?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: I’m curious about the lacking image and firmware versions in that screenshot… also, your latest image is a 2022 one, so that PC doesnt have the 2025 Game Tools installed.  You should definitely do that, or at least test with one that does.

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked:
I have 2025 game tools installed, as you can see in the version number of the imaging tool. The 22.5.0 is the firmware version, not the image (UI glitch on the imaging tool, when you reselect “Format Target” it shows the 2025 image). Because we use a RIO 2, we image the SD cards separately using Balena Etcher, not the imaging tool.

Idk why it doesn’t show the current image and firmware version on the RIO

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: you’re absolutely right. I saw the .cfg file version and didnt look any closer.  Carry on

posts.name: Ben Mick
posts.cooked: I found a solution. Instead of using the IP address settings that the documentation shows, I set my IP address and DNS server to automatic, and it all works now. @kmminer if your problem is still persisting, this might help.

posts.name: Steven Carmain
posts.cooked:
I don’t know where to post this, starting here.

We are trying to follow the VH-109 as a field steps, and they are very vague.  We have 2 teams in our shop, and invite others, so the radio point to point method isn’t easy to support.  We have a field setup with a FMS , and the managed stuff.  But we can’t get the robot to connect to the access point.

First, what firmware do we need to use in each radio?  Is it field radio flashed with the AP firmware?  Do the team radios need to be configured through the Offseason kiosk, or do we just use standard firmware and we just set the keys in the robot radio configuration website?  Do we also have to take off the robot name on the radio to connect to a field?

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
The robot radios can just use the normal 1.3.0 FW, and do not need to be configured using a kiosk.

What is likely happening is the 6 GHz connection is just looking for the format TEAM-Suffix (Or TEAM without any suffix). So thats what you need to enter for the SSID in the AP configuration. Theres no FRC- prefix. And then of course the WPA keys need to match.
